title: 105_s820
content: Accrual rates for members of Congress under CSRS and FERS. Accrual rates for members of Congress under CSRS and FERS are amended by multiplying 2\1/2\ percent of average pay by years of service performed before the beginning of the 106th Congress. Technical amendments are made to sections 8339(c) and 8332(d) of title 5, United States Code. Accrual rates for members of Congress under CSRS and FERS are amended by multiplying 2\1/2\ percent of average pay by years of service performed before the beginning of the 106th Congress. Technical amendments are made to sections 8339(c) and 8332(d) of title 5, United States Code, including changes to section 8415(b) and 8415(g) related to the 1.1 percent accrual rate. The accrual rates for members of Congress under CSRS and FERS are amended by multiplying 2\1/2\ percent of average pay by years of service performed before the beginning of the 106th Congress. For members to whom this subsection applies, the 1.1 percent accrual rate only applies to periods of service not covered by the 1.7 percent accrual rate under subsection (b) or (c). Members of Congress are treated as employees for annuity computations. Members of Congress are treated as employees for annuity computations. Amendments are made to sections 8415, 8422, and 8423 of title 5, United States Code, regarding contributions and deductions from pay for Members. The section specifies the effective date and savings provision for annuity computations for Members of Congress. It will take effect after a 12-month period from the enactment of the Act, and any annuity based on service before this date will be computed according to previous laws. SEC. 3. TWELVE-YEAR LIMITATION ON CREDITABLE SERVICE IN RETIREMENT SYSTEMS FOR MEMBERS OF CONGRESS. Sec. 8410a of Chapter 84 of title 5, United States Code, imposes a limitation on Members of Congress. After serving 12 years, deductions and government contributions for retirement benefits are suspended, but they remain subject to the chapter. Service performed by a Member of Congress after the 105th Congress will be considered for determining entitlement to an annuity, but government contributions will not be made for that period. Service under a different chapter will be treated the same as under this chapter. The term 'Member of the House of Representatives' includes Delegates and the Resident Commissioner from Puerto Rico. The table of contents for chapter 84 of title 5, United States Code, is amended accordingly. Section 8410a of the Civil Service Retirement System limits the benefits for Members of the House of Representatives and Senators after completing 12 years of service. Deductions from pay and government contributions are adjusted accordingly. Government contributions under section 8334(a) are not made for Members of the House. Service as a Member is not considered for annuity calculations, except for disability annuity. Service after the 105th Congress is counted for subsection (a) purposes. The term 'Member of the House of Representatives' includes Delegates and the Resident Commissioner from Puerto Rico. SEC. 4. CONGRESSIONAL RETIREMENT FORFEITURE. The Civil Service Retirement System is amended to exclude the service of individuals convicted of specific offenses while serving as Members. Such individuals are entitled to their lump-sum credit attributable to the excluded service. The offenses must be committed while the individual is a Member for this provision to apply. The offenses that would exclude a Member's service from the Civil Service Retirement System must be directly related to their service, committed during the 106th Congress or later, and fall under specific sections of title 18, such as bribery of public officials and witnesses. The specified offenses that would disqualify a Member from the Civil Service Retirement System must be related to their service, committed during or after the 106th Congress, and include sections of title 18 like bribery, conspiracy, and false claims. The specified offenses that would disqualify a Member from the Civil Service Retirement System must be related to their service, committed during or after the 106th Congress, and include sections of title 18 like bribery, conspiracy, false claims, solicitation of political contributions, intimidation, frauds, swindles, fraud by wire, influencing or injuring officer, and interference with. The offenses that would disqualify a Member from the Civil Service Retirement System include perjury, subornation of perjury, and attempt to evade or defeat tax under specific sections of title 18 and the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. An individual convicted of specified offenses is ineligible for the retirement system while serving as a Member. Regulations will be prescribed to limit interest on lump-sum payments and require the return of vested amounts. This subsection does not restrict any authority. Section 8411 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to state that individuals convicted of certain offenses will not have their service counted for retirement benefits. They will be entitled to receive their lump-sum credit for the service not counted. Individuals convicted of specific offenses during their service as a Member of the 106th Congress or later will not be eligible for retirement benefits under this chapter. The Office will establish regulations, including limiting interest on lump-sum payments for non-eligible individuals. The Executive Director will prescribe regulations for the Thrift Savings Plan, including the return of vested amounts. No restrictions on denying benefits under other laws. The term 'Member' is defined as per section 2106, not section 8401(20).
